bestBHT.bht: A debated point arises regarding the placement of the Lord's Supper in John's narrative. Some suggest it could precede the foot-washing. Uncertainty filled the disciples as they glanced at each other, puzzled about whom Jesus was speaking. Their genuine and generous hearts recoiled at the notion of betrayal, focusing on purging themselves rather than accusing others. These questioning looks expressed their detestation and indignation towards such a heinous act. In this moment of great perplexity, they turned inward to examine their own hearts and guard against hypocrisy.

Henry Alford: We seem called on here to decide a much-controverted question,—where, in St. John’s narrative, the institution of the Lord’s Supper is to be inserted?
I believe certainly before this announcement, as in Luke: and if before it, perhaps before the washing of the disciples’ feet.
For I see no break which would admit it between our ver. 1 and ver. 21.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: The disciples looked one on another, doubting of whom he spake."
Generous, simple hearts! They abhorred the thought, but, instead of putting it on others, each was only anxious to purge himself and know if he could be the wretch."

To prevent this the question is wrung out of him, but perhaps, amidst the stir and excitement at the table, in a half-suppressed tone as we are inclined to think the answer also was—"Thou hast said" (Matthew 26:24- :), or possibly by little more than a sign.
Albert Barnes: Doubting of whom ... - The word translated 'doubting' denotes that kind of anxiety which a man feels when he is in perplexity, and knows not what to say or do."
We should say they were at a loss.
Marvin Vincent: Looked [εβλεπον] . The imperfect tense, kept looking as they doubted.
He spake [λεγει] . The present tense, speaketh, introduced with lively effect.
John Calvin: Satan had expelled from the heart of Judas all reverence, so that it was harder than a rock to reject every admonition.
It is proper that, when the children of God have heard the sentence of the ungodly, they should themselves feel uneasiness, that they may sift themselves, and guard against hypocrisy.
This passage shows that we ought sometimes to reprove the ungodly in such a manner as not instantly to point the finger to them, until God, by his own hand, drag them forth to the light.
Philip Schaff: The disciples looked one on another, in perplexity of whom he spake.
To John, hastening always to the main figure of the scene, it is enough to speak of their looks.
From the parallel passages of the earlier Gospels... we learn that they expressed their perplexity to one another in words.
Archibald T. Robertson: Began to glance at one another in bewilderment.
They recalled their strife about precedence and Judas betrayed nothing.
Indirect question retaining present active indicative.
John Gill: As persons surprised and astonished, and as scarce crediting what was said; not having had the least suspicion of anyone among them, that could be guilty of such an action.
Expressing by their looks their detestation of, and indignation at so horrible an iniquity.
Upon this broad intimation, or rather strong protestation which Christ made, that one of them should betray him, their eyes were not turned to him directly and particularly, but to one another.

bhtAttempts.bht: In this particular passage, there is debate among commentators regarding where the institution of the Lord's Supper should be placed in John's narrative. Some argue that it could come before the washing of the disciples' feet. The disciples, in perplexity, looked at each other, uncertain of whom Jesus was speaking about. This glance at one another expressed their detestation and indignation at the thought that one of them could betray Jesus. Their anxious looks and whispered questioning created an atmosphere of confusion and self-examination, prompting them to sift themselves and guard against hypocrisy. Overall, their genuine and generous hearts abhorred the idea, each one eager to purge himself rather than accuse others.

At this moment, there is a question of where to insert the institution of the Lord's Supper in John's account. Some argue that it could come before the foot-washing ceremony. The disciples, filled with perplexity, looked at each other uncertainly to figure out whom Jesus was referring to. Their anxious glances expressed their detestation and indignation at the thought of one of them betraying Jesus. Their genuine and generous hearts abhorred the idea, each one more concerned with purging themselves than pointing fingers at others.

A debated point arises regarding the placement of the Lord's Supper in John's narrative. Some suggest it could precede the foot-washing. Uncertainty filled the disciples as they glanced at each other, puzzled about whom Jesus was speaking. Their genuine and generous hearts recoiled at the notion of betrayal, focusing on purging themselves rather than accusing others. These questioning looks expressed their detestation and indignation towards such a heinous act. In this moment of great perplexity, they turned inward to examine their own hearts and guard against hypocrisy.

In discussing the progress of events in John's narrative, a dispute arises about where the institution of the Lord's Supper should be situated. It is suggested to precede the washing of the disciples' feet. As Jesus speaks about betrayal, perplexity engulfs the disciples, causing them to cast glances at one another in hesitation. Their genuine and generous hearts abhor the thought of such treachery, prompting them to focus on their own self-reflection rather than hastily accusing others. Their expressions reveal detestation and indignation towards this grievous act.

The placement of the institution of the Lord's Supper within John's narrative is a much-debated question. There are arguments for it occurring before the foot-washing ceremony. The disciples, uncertain of whom Jesus was referring to, exchanged glances filled with bewilderment. Their genuine and generous hearts embraced abhorrence at the thought of betrayal, leading them to focus on personal self-examination rather than accusatory finger-pointing. This shared confusion prompted them to sift themselves and guard against hypocrisy, expressing their detestation and indignation through their questioning looks.
